bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus allowed only Peter, James, and John to accompany Him, excluding the other disciples, perhaps due to the limited space in the house. These three disciples formed a close inner circle, being witnesses to significant events like the Transfiguration and the Garden of Gethsemane. The use of the definite article in Greek suggests that they were treated as a unit. Jesus intentionally restricted the number of witnesses to the miracle, either to avoid distractions or to emphasize the significance of the young woman's restoration to life. While Matthew does not mention this detail, it was important for Mark to highlight. This decision also expressed Jesus' humility, as He was not seeking worldly recognition. Furthermore, the messengers' report of the child's death likely influenced the crowd's departure. By selecting these three disciples as witnesses, Jesus conveyed the importance of their testimony. The mention of James, who was recently martyred, illustrates his prominent position at the time of Mark's writing.
